newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish NFI No.6 to invest up to $10 mln in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Polish NFI No.6 to invest up to $10 mln in 1997.

text.p: Polish National Investment Fund (NFI) Magna Polonia (No.6) wants to invest up to $10 million this year, mostly in companies from its portfolio, the fund's manager said.

"The minimum plan envisages investment of $4-6 million. The maximum envisages $10 million. It seems we will rather go for the maximum version," Krzysztof Bialowolski said. "First of all we will invest in companies from our portfolio."
He said the fund had no plans to float any of its companies on the bourse this year but may introduce one or two firms to the stock exchange in 1998.
"Leather firm Brzeg is our candidate for flotation. We started work to make it public and we expect that it might be listed in 1998," Bialowolski said.
He said the fund's strategy was to increase stakes in chosen companies to some 10 percent from the current 1.93 percent and to sell stakes in the other firms.
NFI No.6, one of 15 such funds created under Poland's mass privatisation programme, has a 33 percent stake in 35 firms and 1.93 percent stakes in almost 500 other firms.
It wants to focus on companies involved in car production, chemicals and consumption goods.
In the first quarter of this year the fund had a net loss of 4.9 million zlotys against a 43.1 million net loss in the whole of 1996.

The 1996 loss was mainly a result of a ruling requiring former state-owned companies to recalculate depreciation for 1995 and the first nine months of 1996 based on gross value of assets rather then net value.
